Burkina Faso has lifted stay at home orders, according to a travel advisory issued on the 6th of August 2020 (this seems like a national measure, so coded as 0). See: https://travel.state.gov/content/travel/en/traveladvisories/traveladvisories/burkina-faso-travel-advisory.html (accessed 21st September 2020, web archive unavailable, travel advisory issued August 6 2020)

There is currently no curfew in place in Burkina Faso. There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. See: https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ (web archive unavailable, accessed 21st September 2020, website last updated 14 September 2020)

Travellers that test positive for COVID-19 upon arrival must quarantine for 14 days at home or in a hotel. There is no quarantine requirement for those with a negative test result. See: https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ (web archive unavailable, accessed 21st September 2020)

COVID-19 testing is free in Burkina Faso. All centres performing COVID-19 diagnostic are contracted by the government. See: https://bf.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ (web archive unavailable, accessed 21st September 2020)

Most businesses in the rest of the country have been able to resume and schools reopen, albeit under strict health protocols.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200913165409/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/376731/botswana-authorities-extend-national-state-of-public-emergency-through-september-30-update-13   According to the UNESCO tracker, the schools are fully open.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200913172643/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse

The government of Botswana declared a State of Public Emergency on 31 March, which has since been extended until 30 September.  The majority of shops, banks and restaurants continue to operate, with precautionary measures in place including the compulsory wearing of face coverings and a requirement to have your temperature taken and to provide your name and contact details when entering.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200913160911/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus

Religious meetings have been permitted with limits on capacity and whilst following social distancing regulations.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200913165409/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/376731/botswana-authorities-extend-national-state-of-public-emergency-through-september-30-update-13

The government of Botswana declared a State of Public Emergency on 31 March, which has since been extended until 30 September. Meetings of more than 50 people remain prohibited.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200913165409/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/376731/botswana-authorities-extend-national-state-of-public-emergency-through-september-30-update-13
According to the US embassy website, buses and vans are operating at full capacity.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200913171400/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
According to the US embassy website, there is no curfew in place.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200913171400/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Air Botswana has resumed domestic flights. Botswana is divided in to nine coronavirus zones. An interzonal travel permit is needed to travel between the coronavirus zones. The Government has announced that those who apply for an interzonal travel permit may require a COVID-19 test if travelling from, returning from or transiting a COVID-19 high risk zone or area.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200913160911/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus

International flights remain suspended and land borders are closed. Humanitarian, cargo, and repatriation flights have continued, though those traveling from high-risk countries are not permitted entry.  https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/376731/botswana-authorities-extend-national-state-of-public-emergency-through-september-30-update-13

The IMF page only talks about tax deferrals.  The government established a Covid-19 Relief Fund with a 2 billion Pula (about 1,1 percent of GDP) contribution from the government that will: i) finance a wage subsidy amounting to 50% of salaries of affected businesses (1000-2500 pula per month for a period of 3 months; ii) finance a waiver on training levy for a period of 6 months (150 million pula). The MoF also decided a tax deferral of 75% of any quarterly payment between March and September 2020 to be paid by March 2021.; iii) Builentities, the procedures for the securitization of loan portfolios are enabled. The amount calculated is Bs. 8,000 million (USD 1,166).  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200921134127/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

CONTACT TRACING   Purpose  This document provides the steps needed to systematically monitor persons at high risk  for COVID-19 infection, as well as to conduct contact tracing of COVID-19 cases in  Botswana, and contacts whom they may have exposed to the disease. In conjunction  with active case finding and testing, and in synergy with other measures such as physical  distancing, contact tracing is recommended in all transmission scenarios.  According to current knowledge, COVID 19 is passed from one person to another primarily  through droplet transmission. People in close contact with COVID-19 cases are at high  risk of being infected with COVID-19, and, if infected, may also transmit the infection to  others. This guideline details how once a COVID-19 case has been identified, the Ministry  of Health and Wellness (MoHW) through District Health Management Teams (DHMT) and  other implementing partners will track, trace and manage people who may have been  exposed to COVID-19.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923115019/https://covid19portal.gov.org.bw/sites/default/files/2020-05/COVID-19-Contact-Tracing-Guideline.pdf

The Director of Disease Control at the Ministry of Public Health, Dr Georges Alain Etoundi Mballa, said 'Cameroon is on track with activities within the fourth operational phase in its response plan against the Covid-19 pandemic'. The public were asked 'to continue with washing hands with clean running water and soap or use an alcohol-based solution; covering the nose and mouth with a disposable tissue when coughing, sneezing or use a bent elbow. People also need to maintain physical distancing of at least 1.5 metres and stay at home as much as possible and wear a face mask when going out.'    https://archive.vn/UBd03

No change in policy. Covid-19 testing is available free of charge (in theory) to those who are symptomatic and eligible. In addition, COVID-19 testing is available in DRC at the traveler's own expense as it is a requirement for domestic and international travel. The cost of a test at a public INRB is US$30 and is higher at private clinics. Testing is available in the 6 main cities (Kinshasa, Matadi, Lubumbashi,  Goma, Kolwezi and Mbandaka). Outside of Kinshasa, the test is performed by medical facilities certified by INRB.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200911141124/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200911141546/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/democratic-republic-of-the-congo/coronavirus  http://web.archive.org/web/20200911141620/https://zoom-eco.net/a-la-une/rdc-les-30-usd-du-test-covid-19-a-linrb-relevent-de-55-les-couts-administratifs-supportes-par-le-voyageur/

"Any passenger who arrives without a negative COVID-19 test result or with a COVID-19 test result dated more than seven days before arrival will have his/her travel documents retained by airport officials and will be subjected to testing. Travelers must self-quarantine at home or at a hotel at their expense until the test result is available.  Any person suspected of having COVID-19, even despite presenting a negative COVID-19 test result, will be isolated at the airport and a COVID-19 test will be conducted.  If test results are positive, that personâs travel documents will be retained, and the traveler will be put into isolation at a government of Mali facility.  The travel documents will be returned once the patient is deemed free of COVID-19. â"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200823213026/https://ml.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

âResolve to Save Lives (RTSL), an initiative of Vital Strategies, provided fast, flexible funds to help recruit and train field epidemiologists.â âThe vast majorityâ¦work on contact tracing teams based in the capital, Nouakchott, where the most transmission was suspected to be occurring.â âEach contact tracing team is comprised of an epidemiologist, an employee of the Ministry of Health, and a driver; each is assigned to one of the capitalâs nineÂ moughataaÂ (districts),Â which vary in population from 20,000 to 300,000. The teams are out in the field from early morning to late at night, tracing contacts of newly diagnosed cases through phone calls and in-person visits. Between those activities, they follow up on calls originally directed to the countryâs public COVID-19 information hotline. Working in shifts, they ensure the governmentâs response to the pandemic continues 24/7.â Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913182428/https://preventepidemics.org/stories/mauritania-getting-eyes-on-the-virus/

Malawi's Education Ministry announced a phased approach to reopening of schools on 28 August, with priority given to Examination classes:    Monday, 7th September, 2020  1. Initial Primary Teacher Education to complete registration processes for examinations;  2. Final Year Students at colleges, universities and examination classes for all schools that offer International curriculum;    Sunday, 20th September, 2020  1. Initial Primary Teacher Education to report to colleges on 20th September;  Phased Re-Opening of Colleges, Universities and International Schools  2. Colleges, universities and schools that offer International curriculum will be allowed to take the second phase of students after three weeks from the day of re-opening (week beginning 28th September, 2020;  3. Since colleges and universities are at different stages, each institution will have to decide which group will have to go first in consultation with the Ministry.    https://archive.vn/g7QwJ

'Authorities in Rwanda on Thursday [3 September] announced new guidelines stipulating fines for people violating health measures put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Private businesses using more than 50% of existing employees will be fined 150,000 Rwandan francs (about $155).'    https://archive.vn/yzs3v

'Authorities in Rwanda on Thursday [3 September] announced new guidelines stipulating fines for people violating health measures put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Hosting mass gatherings for events such as birthday parties or bridal and baby showers will lead to a fine of 200,000 Rwandan francs (about $207). People who attend these events will be liable to pay 25,000 Rwandan francs ($25). Places of worship that reopen without permission will be fined 150,000 Rwandan francs (about $155), while those allowed to reopen will have to pay 100,000 Rwandan francs (about $104) if safety rules are breached.'    https://archive.vn/yzs3v
